'''The psychology of film''' is a sub-field of the [[psychology of art]] that studies the characteristics of [[film]] and its production in relation to [[perception]], [[cognition]], [[narrative]] understanding, and [[emotion]]. A growing number of psychological scientists and brain scientists have begun conducting empirical studies that describe the cognitive and biological underpinnings of motion pictures or what has been called "psychocinematics".<ref name=Shimamura>{{cite book|last=Shimamura|first=Arthur P. (Editor)|title=Psychocinematics: Exploring Cognition at the Movies|year=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press.}}</ref> Early theoretical approaches included works by psychologists [[Hugo Münsterberg]]<ref name="Münsterberg">{{cite book|last=Münsterberg|first=Hugo|title=The Photoplay. A psychological study|year=1916|publisher= Appleton.}}</ref> and [[Rudolf Arnheim]].<ref name=Arnheim>{{cite book|last=Arnheim|first=Rudolf|title=Film as Art: 50th Anniversary Printing|year=2006|publisher=University of California Press.}}</ref> Cognitive film theorists [[David Bordwell]] and [[Noël Carroll]] fostered its philosophical underpinnings.
==Sensory Features== Film is rather unusual as it involves an integration of visual and auditory stimuli. In [[Fictional film|narrative films]], plots are guided by camera placement and movement, dialogue, sound effects, and editing. Some aspects of film are driven by bottom-up or sensory guided factors (such as light, motion or sound), whereas other aspects depend more on top-down or conceptually driven factors, like past experiences and internal motivations.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Park|first=Whan|author2=Daniel C. Smith |title=Product Level Choice: A Top-Down or Bottom-Up Process?|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|date=December 1989|volume=16|issue=3|pages=289–299|doi=10.1086/209215}}</ref>
===Editing===
Cuts and flashbacks represent types of editing that alter the normal temporal sequencing of events, creating non-linear narrative structures. Editing creates the transition between events. Research focusing on recall ability for linear versus non-linear narratives suggests that temporal changes impact memory of events, but not comprehension.<ref name=lowe>{{cite journal|last=Lowe|first=Phillip J.|author2=Durkin, Kevin |title=The effect of flashback on children's understanding of television crime content|journal=Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media|date=1 January 1999|volume=43|issue=1|pages=83–97|doi=10.1080/08838159909364476}}</ref>
Film cuts are instantaneous, perceptual, and sometimes temporal discontinuities that do not exist in our own realities. However, despite this, viewers accept cuts as a natural storytelling technique in film. Even though we see reality in a continuous flow of linked images, in movies, cuts seem to work, regardless of how experienced a viewer is. [[Walter Murch]] suggests that this is because viewers are in fact used to cuts in their everyday lives through the act of [[blinking]]. When you turn to look at an object, for example, you normally blink, thus creating a visual break in continuity between what you ''were'' looking at and what you are now looking at. Another possibility that Murch explores to explain humans’ innate acceptance of film cuts is the way in which we [[dream]]. Our dreams tend to jump around from place to place and situation to situation without any real sense of continuity. Thus the [[Oneiric (film theory)|oneiric]] nature of [[film]]s is familiar to viewers and allows them to innately understand the [[editing]] despite discontinuities.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/33334569|title=In the blink of an eye : a perspective on film editing|last=1943-|first=Murch, Walter,|date=1995|publisher=Silman-James Press|isbn=9781879505230|edition= 1st |location=Los Angeles|oclc=33334569}}</ref>
Schwan & Ildirar (2010), who focused solely on inexperienced viewers’ ability to comprehend film, found that the comprehensibility of films was determined by whether or not they followed a familiar line of action. Overall, our brains accept the perceptual discontinuities found in films, but it is ultimately easier for viewers, regardless of their experience, to understand cuts that follow a continuous and familiar line of action as opposed to ones that are more discontinuous. When a familiar line is not present, more experienced viewers are significantly better at comprehending a complex narrative by “filtering” out editing discontinuities.<ref name="schwan">{{cite journal|last=Schwan|first=S.|author2=Ildirar, S.|date=7 June 2010|title=Watching Film for the First Time: How Adult Viewers Interpret Perceptual Discontinuities in Film|journal=Psychological Science|volume=21|issue=7|pages=970–976|doi=10.1177/0956797610372632|pmid=20530390}}</ref> In the end, however, [[Montage (filmmaking)|montage]] linearity that creates temporal continuity is more important than [[Plot (narrative)|plot]] for recall and understanding of a [[Narrative structure|narrative’s]] events.[[Psychology of film#cite note-cowen-7|<sup>[7]</sup>]]
===Sequence of events===
[[Cognitive neuroscience]] research demonstrates that some movies can exert considerable control over brain activity and eye movements. Studying the neuroscience of film is based on the hypothesis that some films, or film segments, lead viewers through a similar sequence of perceptual, emotional and cognitive states. Using [[fMRI]] brain imaging, researchers asked participants to watch 30 minutes of [[The Good, the Bad and the Ugly]] (1966) as they lay on their backs in the MRI scanner. Despite the seemingly uncontrolled task and complex nature of the stimulus, brain activity was similar across viewers’ brains, particularly in spatiotemporal areas. When compared to a random sequence of scenes, the specific order of events seemed to be strongly associated with this similarity in brain activity. It was also determined that the level of control a movie has on someone’s mental state is highly dependent upon the cinematic devices (pans, cuts and close-ups) it contains. Tightly edited films exert more control on brain activity and eye-movement than open-ended films. However, similar eye-movement and similarity in visual processing does not guarantee similar brain responses.<ref name=hasson>{{cite journal|last=Hasson|first=Uri|author2=Landesman, Ohad |author3=Knappmeyer, Barbara |author4=Vallines, Ignacio |author5=Rubin, Nava |author6= Heeger, David J. |title=Neurocinematics: The Neuroscience of Film|journal=Projections|date=30 August 2008|volume=2|issue=1|pages=1–26|doi=10.3167/proj.2008.020102|citeseerx=10.1.1.454.2650}}</ref> In addition, the average correlation in taste between individual viewers is rather low and not well predicted by film critics.<ref>{{Cite journal|doi = 10.3167/proj.2017.110107|title = Strikingly Low Agreement in the Appraisal of Motion Pictures|journal = Projections|volume = 11|year = 2017|last1 = Wallisch|first1 = Pascal|last2 = Alden Whritner|first2 = Jake}}</ref>
[[File:Friends building.jpg|thumbnail|The Greenwich Village building seen in TV series Friends]]
===Spatial Information===
Viewing spaces on screen from a stable point of view is important for short-term spatial coding and long term spatial memory. Long-time viewers of the television show ''[[Friends]]'' were significantly better at accurately recalling spatial information about the show's set, because the camera never moves away from the "[[fourth wall]]". Equally experienced viewers of the show "[[ER (TV series)|E.R.]]" were less likely to recall information about the set and be able to mentally orient themselves inside it, because the show is filmed from many different angles.<ref name=levin>{{cite journal|last=Levin|first=Daniel T.|author2=Wang, Caryn |title=Spatial Representation in Cognitive Science and Film|journal=Projections|date=1 June 2009|volume=3|issue=1|pages=24–52|doi=10.3167/proj.2009.030103}}</ref>
In one study,<ref name=hirose>{{cite journal|last=Hirose|first=Yoriko|title=Perception and memory across viewpoint changes in moving images|journal=Journal of Vision|date=1 January 2010|volume=10|issue=4|pages=1–19|doi=10.1167/10.4.2|pmid=20465322}}</ref> observers were instructed to look at short movies involving changes in point of view. They used 15 movie clips featuring a handbag, whose properties (color, position, identity, and shape) were manipulated across cuts. Observers' reactions were recorded by examining eye-movement, changes in behavior and memory performance. The researchers later asked the observers if they had noticed anything unusual occur during the clips, without directly referring to the handbag. Changing the position of objects, i.e. the handbag, between scenes was the only variable that did not appear to affect eye-movement or memory. Overall, observers were more likely to draw their attention and look sooner at the handbag-stimulus at the moment right after its properties changed. When specifically asked about it, they were more likely to describe the handbag in terms of its post-cut properties, after a change had occurred. Even though their visual system appeared to pick up on the changes, observers were not consciously aware of them or able to report noticeable differences across cuts. The results illustrate that observers construct and maintain internal visual representations of complex visual environments while viewing dynamic scenes. This also helps explain why movie viewers usually are not aware of continuity errors in editing.<ref name="hirose"/>
===Cinematic techniques===
Cinematic techniques are often regarded as grammatical structures or components of the cinematic art as a language made up of images.<ref name=Messaris94>{{cite book|last=Messaris|first=Paul|title=Visual "Literacy": Image, Mind, Reality|year=1994|publisher=Westview|location=Boulder}}</ref> A period of visual adaptation is necessary before being able to understand images in movies or on [[television]]. Viewers need sufficient exposure to cinematic techniques and the meanings attributed to them to adequately interpret the images on the screen. At a very young age, we learn how to watch videos and understand different editing techniques. One study looked at adult participants who had very little exposure to film to see if they were able to understand simple editing techniques, such as [[point of view shot]]s, [[establishing shot]]s, [[Panning (camera)|pan shots]], [[Shot reverse shot|shot/reverse shot]], ellipsis of time, and [[cross-cutting]]. These viewers were able to understand some of the techniques, such as ellipses of time; however, more complex techniques, like shot/reverse shot were more difficult for them to understand.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Schwan|first=Stephan|author2=Sermin Ildirar |title=Watching Film for the First Time: How Adult Viewers Interpret Perceptual Discontinuities in Film|journal=Association for Psychological Science|date=2010|volume=21|issue=7|pages=969–976|doi=10.1177/0956797610372632|pmid=20530390}}</ref>
Some [[filmmaking]] techniques derive meaning through past experiences or [[Ideology|ideologies]] that influence the way viewers see certain images or sequence of images. An example of this would be how [[camera angle]]s can affect our perception of what is occurring on screen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baranowski|first=Andreas|last2=Hecht|first2=Heiko|date=2017-05-30|title=Effect of Camera Angle on Perception of Trust and Attractiveness|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/317237444|journal=Empirical Studies of the Arts|volume=36|pages=90–100|doi=10.1177/0276237417710762}}</ref> Low angle shots in which the camera is pointed up at a subject tend to make the subject appear more powerful or stronger. While high angle shots can make a subject appear weaker. These interpretations of [[camera angle]]s, however, ultimately derive from the notion that bigger is better. The lateral movement of a subject across the screen can also influence an audience's interpretation of the subject. For example, characters that move from left-to-right are perceived more positively than characters who move right-to-left. This partiality toward rightward movement likely has its roots in the predominance of right-handedness in society,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=L Egizii|first=Matthew|last2=Denny|first2=James|last3=Neuendorf|first3=Kimberly|last4=D Skalski|first4=Paul|last5=Campbell|first5=Rachel|date=2012-05-01|title=Which Way Did He Go? Directionality of Film Character and Camera Movement and Subsequent Spectator Interpretation|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228448619}}</ref> as well as the practice of reading left-to-right in [[Western Romance languages|Western languages]].
====Changes in film techniques====
One study compiled data on the changing trends in techniques by examining 160 English-language films released from 1935-2010.<ref name=cutting>{{cite journal|last=Cutting|first=James E|author2=Brunick, Kaitlin L |author3=DeLong, Jordan E |author4=Iricinschi, Catalina |author5= Candan, Ayse |title=Quicker, faster, darker: Changes in Hollywood film over 75 years|journal=I-Perception|date=1 January 2011|volume=2|issue=6|pages=569–576|doi=10.1068/i0441aap|pmid=23145246|pmc=3485803}}</ref><ref name="cutting" /> The findings demonstrate that over time shot lengths have become shorter, while the shorter the shot the more motion it is likely to contain. In addition, contemporary films have significantly more motion and movement than older ones. Motion is the optical change created by moving objects, people, and shadows; movement is that change created by camera motion or gradual lens change. Presumably, the film industry has capitalized on the results of previous psychological research that shows motion and the onset of motion capture our attention.<ref name=hillstrom>{{cite journal|last=Hillstrom|first=Anne P.|author2=Yantis, Steven |title=Visual motion and attentional capture|journal=Perception & Psychophysics|date=1 July 1994|volume=55|issue=4|pages=399–411|doi=10.3758/BF03205298}}</ref> Finally, films have become darker over time, as the overall brightness of the images on the movie screen has decreased.<ref name="cutting" />
These changes in film-making choices increase attention manipulation and are thought to facilitate comprehension.
==Top-down factors== Top-down factors refer to expectations and background knowledge that influence viewers' perception, understanding and appreciation of film. Expertise, attention and eye-movements are top-down factors that guide how viewers experience film.
===Expertise and awareness of audience manipulation===
Explicit awareness about the processes by which meaning is created by the visual media could be regarded as one measure of film expertise and sophistication. Increased awareness of the subtle techniques employed by filmmakers to “manipulate” audiences leads to increased admiration and aesthetic responses to film,<ref name=gross>{{cite journal|last=Gross|first=L.|title=Art as the communication of competence|journal=Social Science Information|date=1 December 1973|volume=12|issue=6|pages=115–141|doi=10.1177/053901847301200604}}</ref> as in other forms of visual art.<ref>{{cite book|last=Griffith|first=D.W.|title=When the Movies Were Young|year=1975|publisher=Benjamin Blom|location=New York}}</ref> Researchers have identified a strong relationship between prior film experience and conscious awareness of visual manipulations, especially for people with practical experience in production.<ref>{{cite book|last=Worth|first=Sol|title=Through Navajo Eyes: An Exploration in Film Communication and Anthropology|year=1972|publisher=Indiana University Press.|location=Bloomington}}</ref>
One study compared the participants’ ability to understand narrative in Hollywood versus experimental film, by measuring interpretational awareness. Subjects with significant, moderate and no formal background or experience in film viewed a film that contained both scenes with Hollywood-style and experimental-style editing. Regardless of expertise level, participants described the Hollywood-like scenes in “naturalistic terms,” as if their events had occurred in reality and tended not to make explicit references to stylistic techniques. This interpretational tendency reflects Hollywood’s “invisible style.” When describing the experimental scenes, inexperienced viewers struggled to construct a cohesive “naturalistic” narrative. More experienced viewers were more likely to make explicit reference to the “breaking of conventions” and the intentions behind them.<ref name=messaris81>{{cite journal|last=Messaris|first=Paul|title=The Film Audience's Awareness of the Production Process|journal=Journal of the University Film Association|year=1981|volume=33|issue=4|pages=53–56}}</ref>
Film editing seems to be a barrier of awareness for conventional Hollywood-type movies, as they create an illusion of “real life”.
===Segmentation===
Segmentation or event segmentation is a fundamental component of attention that facilitates understanding, object recognition and planning. Event segmentation constitutes breaking down dynamic scenes into spatial and temporal parts or units of events.
Event segmentation is viewed as “the brain’s cutting-room floor.”<ref name=zacksj /> It is considered to be an automatic and ongoing process that depends on meaningful changes in a perceived situation. To test this, researchers measured brain activity while participants viewed an extended narrative film. They used MRI scanning to show transient evoked brain responses (changes in brain activity) at those points they identified as event boundaries (changes in situation). Situational changes were coded frame by frame into spatial, temporal, object, character, causal and goal changes. Participants were then instructed to perform an event segmentation task by watching a movie and pressing a button to identify units of activity that were natural and meaningful to them. Paying attention to situational changes gives rise to a neural cascade that is consciously perceived at the end of one event and the beginning of another.<ref name=zacksj>{{cite journal|last=Zacks|first=J|title=Human Brain Activity Time-locked to Perceptual Event Boundaries|journal=Nature Neuroscience|volume=4|pages=651–655|doi=10.1038/88486|pmid=11369948|year=2001|last2=Braver|first2=TS|last3=Sheridan|first3=MA|last4=Donaldson|first4=DI|last5=Snyder|first5=AZ|last6=Ollinger|first6=JM|last7=Buckner|first7=RL|last8=Raichle|first8=ME|issue=6}}</ref>
According to Event Segmentation Theory (EST),<ref name=zacks>{{cite journal|last=Zacks|first=Jeffrey M.|author2=Speer, Nicole K. |author3=Swallow, Khena M. |author4=Braver, Todd S. |author5= Reynolds, Jeremy R. |title=Event perception: A mind-brain perspective|journal=Psychological Bulletin|date=1 January 2007|volume=133|issue=2|pages=273–293|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.133.2.273|pmid=17338600|pmc=2852534}}</ref> the perception of event boundaries is a side effect of prediction during ongoing perception. Prediction is an adaptive mechanism made up of cognitive event models that represent “what is going on now” to create expectations and attentive biases for ongoing processing. Prediction errors occur at situational changes and cause information processing segmentation.
Broader narrative comprehension theories have also been applied to the perception and memory of movies.<ref name=zacks2>{{cite journal|last=Zacks|first=Jeffrey M.|author2=Speer, Nicole K. |author3=Reynolds, Jeremy R. |title=Segmentation in reading and film comprehension|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: General|date=1 January 2009|volume=138|issue=2|pages=307–327|doi=10.1037/a0015305|pmid=19397386|citeseerx=10.1.1.496.1792}}</ref> This reflects the hypothesis that the same mechanisms are used to understanding stories and real life. In one study, researchers illustrated the common episodic structure between text and film, by asking participants to match a constructed text story to the dialogueless movie [[The Red Balloon]]. This task required participants to locate episodes and their components within the cinematic story: exposition, complication and resolution.<ref name=baggett>{{cite journal|last=Baggett|first=Patricia|title=Structurally equivalent stories in movie and text and the effect of the medium on recall|journal=Journal of Verbal Learning and Verbal Behavior|date=1 June 1979|volume=18|issue=3|pages=333–356|doi=10.1016/S0022-5371(79)90191-9}}</ref>
===Eye-movement===
Using an [[Eye tracking|eyetracker]], researchers have discovered a strong center-of-screen bias with a distribution of gaze points approximately peaking at the screen center. However, eye gazes rarely focus on the same location. Visual dispersion across the screen increases over time and particularly, after repeated exposure to the same video stimulus. Because of this, there is greater gaze dispersion when viewers are watching advertisements compared to a television show.<ref name=brasel>{{cite journal|last=Brasel|first=S Adam|author2=Gips, James |title=Points of view: Where do we look when we watch TV?|journal=Perception|date=1 January 2008|volume=37|issue=12|pages=1890–1894|doi=10.1068/p6253|pmid=19227380|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1230036|format=Submitted manuscript}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Driver|first=J.|title=Parietal neglect and visual awareness|journal=Nature Neuroscience|volume=1|issue=1|pages=17–22|year=1998|doi=10.1038/217|pmid=10195103}}</ref>

[[Provo, Utah]] 84602 |website = https://rsc.byu.edu/ }} {{details|topic=objective study of the LDS Church as an academic field|Mormon studies}} The '''Religious Studies Center''' (RSC) is the research and publishing arm of [[BYU Religious Education|Religious Education]] at [[Brigham Young University]] (BYU), sponsoring scholarship on [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|Latter-day Saint]] (LDS) [[Culture of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|culture]], [[History of the Latter Day Saint movement|history]], [[Standard Works|scripture]], and [[Beliefs and practices of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|doctrine]].{{cite journal | title=Religious Studies Center | journal=Religious Educator | year=2003 | volume=4 | issue=1 | pages=110–111 | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/RelEducator,437 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} The dean of Religious Education serves as the RSC's director, and an associate dean oversees the two branches of the RSC: research and publications. ==History== The RSC (sometimes called the '''Center for Religious Studies''' in its early years){{cite journal | author=Holland, Jeffrey R. | authorlink=Jeffrey R. Holland | title=…Of Countries and of Kingdoms | journal=[[BYU Studies]] | year=1977 | volume=18 | issue=1 | pages=4–5 | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/byustudies,570 | accessdate=2009-05-18}}{{cite book | author=Wilkinson, Ernest L. | authorlink=Ernest L. Wilkinson | title=Brigham Young University: A School of Destiny | year=1976 | publisher=[[BYU Press]] | location=Provo, Utah | page=856 | isbn=0-8425-0905-4}} was founded in 1975 by [[Jeffrey R. Holland]], dean of Religious Education at BYU.{{cite book | chapter=Preface | title=A Book of Mormon Treasury: Gospel Insights From General Authorities and Religious Educators | year=2003 | publisher=Religious Studies Center | location=Provo, Utah | page=ix–x | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/rsc,22453 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} Upon the recommendation of [[List of presidents of Brigham Young University}BYU president]] [[Dallin H. Oaks]], the establishment of the RSC was approved by BYU's Board of Trustees in early 1976. Holland became the RSC's first director, with Keith H. Meservy, assistant professor of ancient scripture, as administrator. In 1976, Holland was appointed [[Church Educational System#Chronology of the Commissioner of Church Education|Commissioner of Church Education]], and [[Ellis T. Rasmussen]] replaced him as dean of Religious Instruction and general director of the RSC.Rasmussen served as dean from 1976-81. See: {{cite journal | author=McCarlie, V. Wallace | title=Sidney B. Sperry: Father of Religious Education at BYU | journal=Religious Education Review | date=Winter 2009 | url=http://byureligiouseducationreview.com/2009WinterSidneySperry.php | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100126183328/http://byureligiouseducationreview.com/2009WinterSidneySperry.php | archivedate=2010-01-26 | df= }}The Religious Education dean is also the RSC general director. For Rasmussen, see: {{cite journal | author=Anderson, Lavina Fielding | authorlink=Lavina Fielding Anderson | title=A Respectful Meeting of the Minds | journal=[[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] | date=June 1978 | page=70| url=http://www.lds.org/ensign/1978/06/a-respectful-meeting-of-the-minds | accessdate=2009-05-18}} The RSC brought together several earlier BYU institutions. It became the home of the '''Richard L. Evans Chair of Christian Understanding''', which had been founded in 1973 with [[Truman G. Madsen]] as its first occupant.{{cite journal | title=Chair of Christian Understanding Founded | journal=[[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] | date=January 1973 | page=138 | url=http://www.lds.org/ensign/1973/01/news-of-the-church/chair-of-christian-understanding-founded | accessdate=2009-05-18}} Madsen became a professor emeritus in 1994, and the position was renamed the '''Richard L. Evans Chair of Religious Understanding''', reflecting the hope that holders would extend the hand of friendship to all people, not just Christians.{{cite journal |last=Grover |first=Steven David |date=2008 |title=Building Bridges: The Richard L. Evans Chair of Religious Understanding |url=https://rsc.byu.edu/archived/volume-9-number-2-2008/building-bridges-richard-l-evans-chair-religious-understanding |journal=Religious Educator |volume=9 |issue=2 |pages=45–56 |publisher=[[Brigham Young University]] |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} The RSC also assumed and expanded upon the activities of the '''Institute of Mormon Studies''', which was founded to study Mormon history and doctrine under [[Daniel H. Ludlow]] in 1961 and Madsen in 1966. Likewise, the RSC absorbed the '''Book of Mormon Institute''', a center for research on the [[Book of Mormon]], with Ludlow as its first director in 1965, followed by [[Paul R. Cheesman]] in 1968. In September 1985, at the request of Holland, then BYU's president, the RSC began holding annual symposia on the Book of Mormon.{{cite book | author=Cheesman, Paul R. | authorlink=Paul R. Cheesman | chapter=Preface | title=The Book of Mormon: The Keystone Scripture: Papers from the First Annual Book of Mormon Symposium | page=ix | year=1988 | publisher=Religious Studies Center | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/rsc,19326 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} The first of these was organized by [[Paul R. Cheesman]], who also edited the published compilation of papers from that event.{{cite web |url=http://files.lib.byu.edu/ead/XML/MSS2049.xml#bio |title=Biographical History |work=Register of the Paul R. Cheesman (1921-1991) Papers, 1945-1991 |publisher=[[Harold B. Lee Library]] |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} Each symposium successively covered following sections of the book{{cite journal | title=A Conversation about the BYU Religious Studies Center | journal=[[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] | date=January 1987 | pages=79–80 | url=http://www.lds.org/ensign/1987/01/news-of-the-church/a-conversation-about-the-byu-religious-studies-center | accessdate=2009-05-18}} until 1994, when papers on the entire book had been published in nine anthology volumes in the ''Book of Mormon Symposium Series''.{{cite book | chapter=Religious Studies Center Publications | editor=[[Monte S. Nyman]] |editor2=Charles D. Kent Brown]] (1985{{snd}}1987), Charles D. Tate Jr. (1987{{snd}}1994), [[Kent P. Jackson]] (1994{{snd}}2001), Richard D. Draper (2001{{snd}}2004), [[Richard N. Holzapfel]] (2004{{snd}}2010), [[Robert L. Millet]] (2010{{snd}}2012), Dana M. Pike (2012{{snd}}2013), Thomas A. Wayment (2013{{snd}}2018), and [https://rsc.byu.edu/faculty-and-staff-profiles Scott C. Esplin] (2018{{snd}}present).{{cite web |url=https://rsc.byu.edu/faculty-and-staff-profiles |title=Faculty and Staff Profiles |website=Religious Studies Center |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} All have significantly influenced the nature and quality of the academic books and journal articles published. In 2001, the dean of Religious Education, Andrew C. Skinner, asked Richard D. Draper to reorganize the center with Holzapfel as editor of the new ''Religious Educator'' journal and [https://rsc.byu.edu/faculty-and-staff-profiles Devan Jensen] as executive editor to professionalize the publications. The RSC created a new advisory board with male and female members from diverse backgrounds with interest in ancient scripture and modern history and doctrine of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church). Draper negotiated a partnership with Covenant Communications to publish RSC materials; that partnership lasted about five years. The ''Religious Educator'' relied on copyediting by Ted D. Stoddard with design work by Stephen Hales Creative, based in Provo, Utah. Holzapfel started a project to digitize past RSC content; initiated translation of selected articles into Spanish, Portuguese, and German; and launched the ''BYU Religious Education Review'' magazine. Under the leadership of directors Millet, Pike, and Wayment, publications continued to win awards (see list below) and reach a wider audience. ==Purpose== The RSC seeks to improve religion teaching at BYU, to encourage LDS religious studies, and to promote the study of other religions. Believing that [[General Authority|church leaders]], not scholars, are the ultimate doctrinal authority, the RSC seeks to only add historical, cultural, and linguistic context and to explore new views of the LDS religious tradition. The RSC coordinates and publishes this research{{cite journal | author=Waterman, Bryan | title=A Guide to the Mormon Universe: Mormon Organizations & Periodicals | journal=[[Sunstone Magazine|Sunstone]] | date=December 1994 | issue=97 | page=52 | format=[[PDF]] | url=http://www.sunstonemagazine.com/pdf/097-44-65.pdf | accessdate=2009-05-18}} in the hopes of growing the body of LDS literature and thought. In 1977, as Church Commissioner of Education, Holland told the center that he hoped it would bring dialogue with other cultures and religions, leading to greater understanding, brotherhood, and peace. Later, as president of BYU in 1986, Holland recalled that the RSC was established to inform those within the university and the general LDS membership.{{cite web | author=Holzapfel, Richard N. | authorlink=Richard N. Holzapfel | title=It's a classic! | date=October 21, 2008 | work=RSC Blog | url=http://rsc.byu.edu/blog/?p=4 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} In 2008, the RSC began posting its complete library in English and selections in Spanish and Portuguese in order to increase its worldwide presence.http://rsc.byu.edu/{{full citation needed|date=July 2014}} ==Activities== ===Areas of study=== The RSC has funded research in several areas, including ancient scripture,{{cite book | chapter=Religious Studies Center, Brigham Young University | page=v | title=Nibley on the Timely and the Timeless: Classic Essays of Hugh Nibley | year=1978 | publisher=Religious Studies Center | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/rsc,16986 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} ancient studies, the [[Bible]],{{cite book | chapter=Religious Studies Center, Brigham Young University | page=v | title=Excavations at Seila, Egypt | editor=[[C. Wilfred Griggs]] | year=1988 | publisher=Religious Studies Center | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/rsc,7821 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} the [[Book of Mormon]], Church history, the [[Doctrine and Covenants]], Judeo-Christian Religions, the [[Pearl of Great Price (Latter Day Saints)|Pearl of Great Price]], and world religions. The RSC has also sponsored LDS sociological studies{{cite book | title=The Religion and Family Connection: Social Science Perspectives | editor=Darwin L. Thomas | publisher=Religious Studies Center | year=1988}}{{cite book | editor=Duke, James T. | title=Latter-day Saint Social Life: Social Research on the LDS Church and Its Members | publisher=Religious Studies Center | year=1998}}{{cite journal | author=Dollahite, David C. | title=Beloved Children, Faithful Fathers: Caring for Children with Special Needs | journal=Marriage & Families | date=August 2001 | issue=6 | page=21 | format=[[PDF]] | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/MarriageandFamily,26 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} and research on other religions, such as [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria#History|early Egyptian Christianity]], [[Islam]], and [[sub-tropical]] [[Religion in Africa|African religions]]. In 1985, the RSC began to publish works from some of these specialized areas of study, making up the RSC Specialized Monograph Series. ===Research and funding=== The RSC awards [[Grant (money)|financial grants]] to BYU faculty and other scholars for research into LDS history, doctrine, scripture, and culture.{{cite web|title=Research Grants |work=Religious Studies Center |publisher=[[Brigham Young University]] |url=http://rsc.byu.edu/rsc_grants.php |accessdate=2009-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427210825/http://rsc.byu.edu/rsc_grants.php |archivedate=April 27, 2009 }} This research has been published by the RSC{{cite book | author=Skousen, Royal | authorlink=Royal Skousen | chapter=The Book of Mormon Critical Text Project | page=65 | editor=[[Susan Easton Black]] |editor2=Charles D. Tate, Jr. | title=Joseph Smith, The Prophet, The Man | year=1993 | publisher=Religious Studies Center | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/rsc,21250 | accessdate=2009-05-18}}{{cite book | author=Sperry, Kip | chapter=Acknowledgments | page=xiv | title=Kirtland, Ohio: A Guide to Family History and Historical Sources | year=2005 | publisher=Religious Studies Center | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/rsc,16169 | accessdate=2009-05-18}}{{cite book | author=Jackson, Richard W. | chapter=Introduction | page=ix | title=Places of Worship: 150 years of Latter-day Saint Architecture | year=2003 | publisher=Religious Studies Center | url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/rsc,2890 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} and other publishers, including ''[[Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought]]'',[[Marie Cornwall]]'s work on the article "[http://content.lib.utah.edu/u?/dialogue,18500 How Common the Principle?: Women as Plural Wives in 1860]" was partially funded by the RSC. Walker | title=Wayward Saints: The Godbeites and Brigham Young | year=1998 | publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]] | url=https://books.google.com/?id=gBDKrHzY1OQC&pg=PT1&dq=%22religious+studies+center%22 | accessdate=2009-05-18 | isbn=978-0-252-06705-1}} the [[University of Missouri Press]],{{cite book | author=Launius, Roger D. | chapter=Preface | page=xiv | title=Alexander William Doniphan | year=1997 | publisher=[[University of Missouri Press]] | url=https://books.google.com/?id=xhneotO7Xg8C&pg=PP20&dq=%22religious+studies+center%22 | accessdate=2009-05-18 | isbn=978-0-8262-1132-3}} and [[Oxford University Press]].{{cite book | author=Hamilton, C. Mark | title=Nineteenth-Century Mormon Architecture and City Planning | chapter=Acknowledgments | page=ix | publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] | year=1995 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=4MeO4oOVaawC&pg=PP10&dq=%22religious+studies+center%22 | accessdate=2009-05-18 | isbn=978-0-19-507505-2}} Of the several projects it accepts per year, the RSC prefers those that benefit religious teachers and the progress of the LDS Church. RSC publications are intended to be scholarly and useful to general LDS readers. The RSC is financed through BYU funds, individual donations, and the Friends of Religious Education (FORE).{{cite web | title=Friends of Religious Education | work=Religious Education | publisher=[[Brigham Young University]] | url=http://religion.byu.edu/about_fore.php | accessdate=2009-05-18}} FORE is a national volunteer committee to find donors for BYU Religious Education activities,{{cite journal | author=Nordgren, Brent R. | title=A Conversation with Ken McCarty | date=Winter 2009 | page=18 | journal=BYU Religious Education Review | format=[[PDF]] | url=http://byureligiouseducationreview.com/2009WinterFiles/2009WinterWeb.pdf | accessdate=2009-05-18}} such as RSC research, publishing, and translation. FORE encourages donations, sponsors projects, and hosts [[Fireside (LDS Church)|firesides]] (special religious lectures) throughout the United States given by Religious Education faculty.{{cite journal | title=Invitation from Friends of Religious Education | date=Winter 2009 | series=[back cover] | journal=BYU Religious Education Review | format=[[PDF]] | url=http://byureligiouseducationreview.com/2009WinterFiles/2009WinterWeb.pdf | accessdate=2009-05-18}} ===Books=== The following titles show the breadth of books published by the RSC ([https://rsc.byu.edu/books complete list]): Andrew F. Ehat and Lyndon W. Cook, eds., ''The Words of Joseph Smith''; Hugh W. Nibley, ''Nibley on the Timely and the Timeless''; Kenneth L. Alford, ed., ''Civil War Saints''; [[Roger P. Theodore Tuttle in South America, 1960–1965''; Laura Harris Hales, ed., ''A Reason for Faith: Navigating LDS Doctrine and Church History''; and Michael Hubbard MacKay and Nicholas J. Frederick, ''Joseph Smith's Seer Stones''. Several have won awards (see list below). ===Symposia and Conferences=== A primary function of the RSC is the organization of symposia and conferences on religious subjects, from which selected papers are later published. Anthologies from symposia on broad topics make up several volumes in the RSC Monograph Series.{{cite book |last=Porter |first=Larry C. |year=1985 |title=Supporting Saints: Life Stories of Nineteenth-Century Mormons |url=https://rsc.byu.edu/out-print/supporting-saints-life-stories-nineteenth-century-mormons |pages=xi–xii |publisher=Religious Studies Center |location=Provo, Utah |chapter=Foreword |chapterurl=https://rsc.byu.edu/archived/supporting-saints-life-stories-nineteenth-century-mormons/foreword-and-introduction |isbn=0-8849-4565-0 |accessdate=November 15, 2017}}{{cite journal |last=Moorty |first=S. S. |date=Winter 1982 |title=Unity in Diversity |journal=[[Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought]] |page=127 |volume=15 |issue=4 |url=https://www.dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V15N04_127.pdf |accessdate=November 15, 2017}}{{cite journal | author=Woodward, Robert C. | title=Study in Mutual Respect | journal=[[Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought]] | page=155 | date=Spring 1984 | volume=17 | issue=1 | url=http://content.lib.utah.edu/u?/dialogue,14463 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} Some of these symposia recur annually, such as ones on scriptures and church history. The RSC is also involved with the annual [[Sidney B. Sperry Symposium]], which have been held at BYU since 1973.{{cite book | chapter=Sperry, Sidney B. | author=Rasmussen, Ellis T. | title=Encyclopedia of Latter-day Saint History | editor=[[Richard O. Cowan]] |editor2=[[Donald Q. Cannon]] |editor3=[[Arnold K. Garr]] | publisher=[[Deseret Book]] | location=Salt Lake City, Utah | year=2000}} Often, [[general authorities]] deliver the keynote addresses at these symposia. In 2003 the Religious Education Administrative Council approved a proposal by Richard Neitzel Holzapfel and Thomas A. Wayment to host a conference on the Saturday before Easter which would focus on Jesus's last twenty-four hours and Resurrection. The conference was held and rebroadcast on KBYU Television, helping Religious Education expand its audience. The response to this conference, now called the [http://rsc.byu.edu/easterconference BYU Easter Conference], was so positive that the university decided it should be an annual event, cosponsored by Religious Education and the RSC. Early on, nearly one thousand attendees heard Elder D. Todd Christofferson give the keynote address at the second annual conference, "The Atonement and the Resurrection," later published in the ''Religious Educator''. In subsequent years, the event was shifted to Fridays, often targeted to coincide with Good Friday. Over the years keynote addresses were delivered by President [[Cecil O. Samuelson]] in 2006, Elder F. Enzio Busche in 2007, and Sister [[Bonnie D. Parkin]] in 2009. An estimated 2,500 people attended the 2013 Easter Conference that featured Elder [[John M. Madsen]], [[Bradley R. Wilcox|Brad Wilcox]], and [[Brent L. Top]]. Other well-known keynote addresses have been given by [[Elaine S. Dalton]], [[Spencer J. Condie]], [[Sheri L. Dew]], and BYU president, [[Kevin J Worthen]].https://rsc.byu.edu/easterconference The annual event has stayed quite popular among people living along the [[Wasatch Front]]. The proceedings are published every other year by the RSC in cooperation with [[Deseret Book]]. In 2006 the RSC began sponsoring the [http://rsc.byu.edu/conferences Church History Symposium], copublishing the proceedings with [[Deseret Book]]. Professor [[Alexander L. Baugh]] initiated the event by proposing a conference to acknowledge the two hundredth anniversary of [[Oliver Cowdery]]'s birth. Since that time, this event has become a premier venue for rigorous and faithful scholarship on Church history. The topics have been Oliver Cowdery,{{cite web|url=http://rsc.byu.edu/recent-books-archived/days-never-be-forgotten-oliver-cowdery|title=Days Never to Be Forgotten: Oliver Cowdery|publisher=Rsc.byu.edu|accessdate=17 October 2014}} [[Wilford Woodruff]],{{cite web |url=https://rsc.byu.edu/recent/banner-gospel-wilford-woodruff |title=Banner of the Gospel: Wilford Woodruff |website=Religious Studies Center |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} [[John Taylor (Mormon)|John Taylor]],{{cite web|url=http://rsc.byu.edu/archived/champion-liberty-john-taylor|title=Champion of Liberty: John Taylor|publisher=Rsc.byu.edu|accessdate=17 October 2014}} "Preserving the History of the Latter-day Saints,"{{cite web|url=https://rsc.byu.edu/recent/preserving-history-latter-day-saints|title=Preserving the History of the Latter-day Saints|publisher=Rsc.byu.edu|accessdate=17 October 2014}} "A Firm Foundation: Church Organization and Administration,"{{cite web|url=https://rsc.byu.edu/recent/firm-foundation-administrative-and-organizational-history-church|title=A Firm Foundation|publisher=Rsc.byu.edu|accessdate=17 October 2014}} "Go Ye into All the World: The Growth and Development of Mormon Missionary Work,"{{cite web|url=https://rsc.byu.edu/recent-books/go-ye-all-world|title=Go Ye into All the World|publisher=Rsc.byu.edu|accessdate=17 October 2014}} "Joseph F. Smith: Reflections on the Man and His Times,"{{cite web |url=https://rsc.byu.edu/churchhistorysymposium/2014 |title=2014 BYU Church History Symposium |website=Religious Studies Center |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} "Approaching Antiquity: Joseph Smith's Study of the Ancient World,"{{cite web |url=https://religion.byu.edu/event/2013-byu-church-history-symposium |title=2013 BYU Church History Symposium |website=[[Brigham Young University]] |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} "The International Church: Mormonism as a Global Religion,"{{cite web |url=https://religion.byu.edu/news/2014-byu-church-history-symposium-world-wide-church-global-reach-mormonism |title=2014 BYU Church History Symposium: "The World Wide Church: The Global Reach of Mormonism" |website=[[Brigham Young University]] |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} "Beyond Biography: Sources in Context for Mormon Women's History," {{cite web |url=https://religion.byu.edu/2016-church-history-symposium |title=2016 Church History Symposium |website=[[BYU Division of Continuing Education]] |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} and "Financing Faith: The Intersection of Business and Religion."{{cite web |url=https://churchhistory.ce.byu.edu/ |title=Church History Symposium |website=[[BYU Division of Continuing Education]] |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} ===Periodicals=== In addition to books and articles, the RSC publishes its own periodicals. In 1986 the RSC began publishing the quarterly (later triannual) ''Religious Studies Center Newsletter'', which carried updates on RSC symposia, books, and research, and was distributed to Church Educational System faculty and LDS military chaplains. In 2008 the newsletter was replaced by ''BYU Religious Education Review'', a semiannual magazine.{{cite web |url=http://catalog.lib.byu.edu/uhtbin/cgisirsi/?ps=VG1FAxkplw/LEE/152540253/8/2016759/BYU+religious+education+review |title=BYU Religious Education Review |website=[[Harold B. Lee Library]] |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} In 2000, Dean Robert L. Millet and others created the ''Religious Educator'' journal to focus on "teaching the gospel, publishing studies on scripture, doctrine, and LDS Church history, and sharing the messages of outstanding devotional essays."''Religious Educator'' 1 (2000): i. Millet replaced the temporary editorial board in 2001 with Richard Neitzel Holzapfel, who became the full-time editor in chief. Holzapfel asked Ted D. Stoddard, a professor in the Marriott School of Business, to explore design and content issues and prepare guidelines that would enhance the scholarly basis of this new publication. Holzapfel clarified the purpose of this new venture: "Our hope is to provide readers with carefully prepared, inspirational, and information-packed writings on a wide range of subjects explicitly associated with the Restoration. Teachers, authors, researchers, and students of Latter-day Saint studies at every level will appreciate discussions of relevant ideas and issues from a perspective of faith."''Religious Educator'' 3, no. 2 (2002): vi The main audience consists of Church Educational System teachers, such as volunteers and paid professionals in [[LDS Seminaries]] and [[Institutes of Religion]] and religion professors at church colleges.{{cite journal |title=The Religious Educator: Perspectives on the Restored Gospel |journal=Religious Educator |date=Spring 2000 |volume=1 |issue=1 |page=i |url=http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/RelEducator/id/376 |accessdate=November 15, 2017}} In 2007 the RSC agreed to oversee and help fund the student journal ''Studia Antiqua''. ===Awards=== *2018: Smith-Pettit Best Book Award ([[John Whitmer Historical Association]]) for Roy A. Yasuhisa Kazama | writer = [[Ryōsuke Takahashi]] | music = Osamu Totsuka | studio = [[Sunrise (company)|Sunrise]] | licensee = {{English anime licensee|NA= [[Discotek Media]]}} | first = 21 March 1991 | last = 23 August 1991 | runtime = | episodes = 5 | episode_list = List of Ronin Warriors episodes#Ronin Warriors: Message }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | title = Shin Yoroiden Samurai Troopers | author = Izumi Nikaidō | illustrator = Yūji Hosoi | publisher = [[Kodansha]] | demographic = ''[[Children's manga|Kodomo]]'' | magazine = [[Comic BonBon|Comic BonBon Deluxe]] | published = 1992 | volumes = 1 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} '''''Ronin Warriors''''', known in Japan as {{nihongo|'''''Legendary Armor Samurai Troopers'''''|鎧伝サムライトルーパー|Yoroiden Samurai Torūpā}}, is a Japanese [[anime]] series and [[manga]] adaptation created by [[Hajime Yatate]]. The anime was produced and animated by [[Sunrise (company)|Sunrise]] and [[Nagoya Broadcasting Network|Nagoya TV]], and aired across Japan on the [[TV Asahi]] network from 30 April 1988 to 4 March 1989 and has a total of 39 episodes. The manga ran from November 17, 1988 to April 5, 1990 and consists of 2 volumes which were published by Kodansha. ''Ronin Warriors'' was produced by [[Graz Entertainment]] and distributed by [[Cinar]], and it was recorded by the [[Vancouver]]-based [[Ocean Productions]] cast. ''Ronin Warriors'' first aired on American television during the summer of 1995 and subsequently appeared through syndication, as well as the [[USA Network]] and later on [[Cartoon Network]]. The series was released on DVD in 2002, including the original Japanese version with English subtitles on the reverse side of the disc. On September 4, 2014, North American anime licensor [[Discotek Media]] announced their license of the original Japanese anime (''Yoroiden Samurai Troopers''), and plans to release the series on DVD.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-09-05/discotek-adds-samurai-troopers-bokurano-comic-party-3rd-lupin-iii-tv-special/.78423|title=Discotek Adds Samurai Troopers, Bokurano, Comic Party, 3rd Lupin III TV Special|publisher=Anime News Network|date=2014-09-05}} Discotek has said that they have no plans to release ''Ronin Warriors'' until they clear issues with the dub. Discotek has also licensed the OVAs and will include both Japanese and English audio as well as English subtitles. The opening and ending sequences and the [[eyecatch]]es were replaced with new ones, and the Japanese title cards were removed; there were no substantial cuts to the bodies of the episodes and the episodes retained most of the original music. Three direct-to-video sequels were produced: ''Gaiden'' (''Side Story''), ''Kikoutei Densetsu'' (''The Legend of the Solar Armor'') and ''Message''. There is also a ''Ronin Warriors'' [[manga]] as well as numerous novels and audio dramas based on the anime. While all the sequels have been released on DVD, the manga and audio dramas have not been made available in English. ==Plot== {{main article|List of Ronin Warriors characters|List of Ronin Warriors episodes}} [[List of Ronin Warriors characters#Talpa|Talpa]], the demon lord of the Netherworld, is bent on conquering the mortal world. Standing against Talpa and his four Dark Warlords are the five Ronin Warriors, each in possession of mystical armor and weapons. They are assisted by [[List of Ronin Warriors characters#Mia Koji|Mia Koji]], a young student-teacher, and a mysterious warrior-monk known only as [[List of Ronin Warriors characters#The Ancient {{Use British English|date=December 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} '''Shape Arts''' or '''Shape''' is a London-based arts charity, funded by [[Arts Council England]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/funding/browse-regularly-funded-organisations/npo/shape-london |title=Browse: National portfolio organisations |publisher=Arts Council |date= |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> that is committed to providing opportunities for disabled individuals wanting to work in the arts and cultural sector. It trains participants and runs arts and development programmes across all of the creative arts: visual arts, music, dance, writing and acting. Shape Arts partners with major cultural institutions to create positive change for disabled people by improving access, exposure and opportunities in contemporary art.
==History== Shape was founded by Gina Levete MBE in 1976 with project funding from the [[Gulbenkian Foundation]].<ref name="shapearts1">{{cite web|url=http://www.shapearts.org.uk/shape-at-a-glance |title=Shape at a glance |publisher=Shape Arts |date= |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> The current CEO is [[Tony Heaton]] OBE.<ref>{{cite web |last=Evans |first=Kim |date=2011-03-15 |title=Tony Heaton: joining the national network |url=http://www.culturalleadership.org.uk/375/ |publisher=Cultural Leadership Programme |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref>
Shape was informed by the political activism of the 60s. [[Disability arts]] grew out of the [[disability rights movement]], and the wider struggle by disabled people for equality and the right to participate in all aspects of society.<ref name="shapearts1"/>
==Activities== Their mission is to provide skills, opportunities and support for disabled artists, individuals and cultural organisations; and help build a more inclusive cultural sector. It does this through four delivery aims:
*More disabled people employed in the creative industries *More disabled people as audiences *Disabled artists creating high quality creative work *Disabled people participating in the arts
Shape Arts arranges exhibitions,<ref>{{cite web|author=disabilityhorizons |url=http://disabilityhorizons.com/open-to-art |title=Calling all disabled artists | Disability and art |publisher=Disabilityhorizons.com |date=2012-02-16 |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> awards bursaries to promising disabled artists<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disabilityartsonline.org/?location_id=1781 |title=News: Shape Arts announces winner of the Adam Reynolds Bursary 2012 |publisher=disability arts online |date=2012-06-25 |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> and provides training in media and marketing skills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communitydance.org.uk/DB/events-and-training-8/online-training-events-creative-steps-shape-arts.html |title=Foundation for Community Dance :: Online Training Events – Creative Steps – Shape Arts |publisher=Communitydance.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-22}}</ref> From December 2012 - Spring 2013, a [[pop-up retail|pop-up]] exhibition entitled 'Shape in the City' was presented in the centre of the City of London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londonpopups.com/2012/12/shape-arts-pop-up-gallery-in-city.html |title=Shape Arts Pop-up Gallery in The City |publisher=London Pop-ups |date=2012-12-11 |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> Shape recently had a temporary exhibition space for two years - a gallery at [[Westfield Stratford City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shapearts.org.uk/visit-shape-gallery |title=Visit Shape Gallery |publisher=Shape Arts |date= |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref>
==Notable artists== *[[Yinka Shonibare]] is a disabled artist who worked as an arts development officer at Shape in the 90s. Shonibare acknowledges the role that Shape Arts played in his early career: "I worked for Shape three days a week, running workshops on singing, dancing or visual arts for disabled and older people in day centres and hospitals. The job meant I could afford to rent a studio and it gave me organisational and fundraising skills."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disabilitynow.org.uk/entertainment/arts/an-artist-with-a-lot-of-bottle |title=An artist with a lot of bottle — Disability Now |publisher=Disabilitynow.org.uk |date=2012-01-14 |accessdate=2012-08-14}}</ref> In 2013, Shonibare was announced as patron of the annual Shape 'Open' exhibition where disabled and non-disabled artists are invited to submit work in response to a disability focused theme.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shape Open exhibition Patron Announced|url=http://www.shapearts.org.uk/news/shape-open-exhibition-patron-announced.aspx|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Yinka Shonibare MBE Announces Winner of Shape Open 2013 |url=https://www.shapearts.org.uk/Blog/yinka-shonibare-mbe-announces-winner-of-shape-open-2013 |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref> *[[Guy Evans]], a founding member of [[Echo City]], is a [[progressive rock]] drummer with [[Subterraneans (band)|Subterraneans]] who worked at Shape Arts in an administrative role and as a workshop leader.<ref>{{cite web|title=Unique music |url=https://ccskills.org.uk/careers/advice/article/unique-music |website=ccskills.org.uk |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> *[[Kelly Knox]], one of Britain's leading disabled fashion models, worked at Shape Arts for a number of years as a programme co-ordinator.
==Financial Support== Renowned British contemporary artists have donated artworks to Shape to raise money for the charity through an auction at [[Bonhams]]. Funds raised from the sale were matched by the Arts Council’s Catalyst Arts Fund and went towards supporting new arts activities and opportunities for disabled people. Works by [[Jake and Dinos Chapman]], [[Mat Collishaw]], [[Angela de la Cruz]], [[Tacita Dean]], Sir [[Antony Gormley]], [[Marc Quinn]] and [[David Shrigley]] were auctioned at Bonhams London on 4 March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shapearts.org.uk/Blog/shapes-inaugural-contemporary-art-fundraiser |title=Blog | Shape's Inaugural Contemporary Art Fundraiser |publisher=Shape Arts |date= |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref>
In 2016, an online auction at [[Paddle8]] included donations of twenty-five artworks from a range of internationally acclaimed artists including [[Jeremy Deller]], [[Julie Umerle]], [[Candida Hofer]], [[Ragnar Kjartansson (sculptor)|Ragnar Kjartansson]], [[Hito Steyerl]], [[Grayson Perry]] and [[Hans Op de Beeck]] in support of Shape Arts' 40th anniversary and the continued importance of the organisation's work.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shapearts.org.uk/Event/shape-art-auction |title=Shape Benefit Art Auction & Exhibition |publisher=Shape Arts |date= |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Hutchinson |url=https://www.a-n.co.uk/news/shape-arts-40th-anniversary-auction-raises-27k |title=Shape Arts 40th anniversary auction raises £27,000 « a-n The Artists Information Company |publisher=A-n.co.uk |date=2016-04-26 |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref>
== Adam Reynolds' Memorial Bursary ==
The Adam Reynolds Memorial Bursary was inaugurated in 2008 in memory of the sculptor Adam Reynolds (1959-2005). It is one of the most significant opportunities for disabled visual artists in the UK, offering an opportunity to engage in a three-month residency at a high-profile gallery. Venues that have hosted the residencies include the [[V & A]], [[Camden Arts Centre]], [[Spike Island, Bristol|Spike Island]], The [[BALTIC]], the [[Bluecoat Gallery]] and [[New Art Gallery Walsall]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disabilityartsonline.org.uk/Adam-Reynolds-Memorial-Bursary-Shape-The-First-Four |title=Discussion: John O'Donoghue gives an overview of the Shape's Adam Reynolds Memorial Bursary: The First Four |publisher=disability arts online |date=2013-06-14 |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref>
